choices.text: Sensory level is from T10 to L1
Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8
In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1
In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding innervation of the uterus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

 

Explanation:

 

The incorrect statement regarding the innervation of the uterus is option B. Uterine contractility is primarily mediated by hormonal mechanisms rather than by specific spinal innervations. Hormones such as estrogen, prostaglandins, and oxytocin play a significant role in inducing uterine contractions, while progesterone helps maintain uterine relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1: The sensory innervation of the uterus is indeed from spinal levels T10 to L1. These afferent fibers enter the spinal cord via the inferior hypogastric plexus and are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the uterus.

 

Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1: During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1. This pain is due to the distension of the cervix and lower uterine segment, as well as the contraction of the uterus.

 

Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction: In early labor, pain is usually related to uterine contractions, which stimulate nociceptors in the genital tract and can cause discomfort and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine contractility is not mediated by innervations from spinal level T7 - T8; instead, it is primarily influenced by hormonal mechanisms.

 

 

Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Which is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B + C (Posterolateral variety and Bochdalek hernia)

 

The most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the Bochdalek hernia, which occurs in the posterolateral part of the diaphragm. This type of hernia typically presents with abdominal organs, such as the intestines, herniating into the chest cavity, leading to respiratory distress in newborns due to lung compression. Bochdalek hernias account for about 85-90% of all congenital diaphragmatic hernias, making them the most common type.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Anteromedial variety: This is a less common form of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and typically occurs in the anterior or medial portion of the diaphragm, which is not the usual presentation associated with congenital cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the Bochdalek hernia, which is located in the posterolateral part of the diaphragm.

questions.text: In the presence of tracheal deviation as indicated on a chest X-ray, which procedure is the most difficult to perform? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

A tracheostomy involves creating an opening through the neck into the trachea, which may become complicated when the trachea is deviated. In cases of tracheal deviation, the trachea is not in its usual midline position, which can make locating the correct spot for incision more challenging. This difficulty is increased because the trachea's position may not be easily palpable or visible due to its displacement, which can complicate the procedure and increase the risk of complications.

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal airway: A laryngeal airway (LMA) is inserted above the larynx at the supraglottic level. Since this procedure does not involve the trachea directly, a deviated trachea does not affect the placement of an LMA, making it relatively easy to perform.

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: While endotracheal intubation may become slightly more difficult with tracheal deviation, it usually remains manageable. The main challenge might be encountering some resistance or needing to adjust the angle of the tube. However, with careful maneuvering, the endotracheal tube can still be guided into the trachea.

Option D. Cricothyroidotomy: This procedure involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane, located above the trachea at the level of the larynx. Because the tracheal deviation occurs below this point, it does not directly impact the cricothyroidotomy, making it a viable option even with tracheal deviation.

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy can be more challenging in cases of tracheal deviation due to the altered position of the trachea, making the precise location for incision difficult to identify.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Montgomery T tube

 

Montgomery T tube is a type of silicone stent used in the management of tracheal and subglottic stenosis. It is T-shaped to allow it to fit snugly in the trachea with one limb exiting the stoma, allowing for breathing through the upper airway or the tube itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a device inserted between the trachea and the esophagus to facilitate speech in patients who have had a total laryngectomy

 

Option C. Blom-Singer prosthesis is a type of tracheoesophageal puncture voice prosthesis used for voice rehabilitation after a laryngectomy. When a patient has their larynx removed, typically due to cancer, they lose their natural voice. A Blom-Singer prosthesis is a one-way valve inserted between the trachea and the esophagus that allows air to be diverted into the esophagus to produce sound, enabling the patient to speak. It is placed during surgery or as an office procedure after the surgical site has healed.

 

Option D. A Grommet, also known as a tympanostomy tube or ventilation tube, is a small tube inserted into the eardrum to allow air to enter the middle ear. It is used to treat recurrent middle ear infections (acute otitis media) or to relieve chronic fluid accumulation in the middle ear (otitis media with effusion). Grommets help reduce the frequency of ear infections and improve hearing by allowing the continuous drainage of fluid and equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the external atmospheric pressure.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the association between the consumption of vegetarian/non-vegetarian food with certain diseases. The incidence of disease was evaluated in those two groups. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used when evaluating the association between categorical variables, such as the consumption of vegetarian or non-vegetarian food and the incidence of certain diseases. This study involves comparing the occurrence of diseases in two groups (vegetarians vs. non-vegetarians), which represents qualitative data.

 

The Chi-square test is specifically designed for non-parametric data (data that does not follow a normal distribution) and is ideal for comparing proportions, percentages, or counts between two or more groups. In this context, the test helps determine whether there is a significant association between diet type and disease occurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Paired student’s t-test: The paired student’s t-test is used for comparing means within the same group at two different times (before and after an intervention). It is suitable for continuous data, not for comparing categorical data between two distinct groups.

 

Option B. Unpaired student’s t-test: The unpaired student’s t-test compares the means of two independent groups, such as test scores or measurements. This test is used for continuous, normally distributed data and is not suitable for categorical or qualitative data like the incidence of diseases.

 

Option D. Wilcoxon test: The Wilcoxon test is a non-parametric test used for comparing two paired groups when the data is not normally distributed. It is similar to the paired t-test but for ordinal or continuous data, making it unsuitable for categorical data such as disease incidence.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chi-square test is used to determine the association between categorical variables, especially when comparing the incidence of outcomes across two or more independent groups.

choices.text: Oral hairy Leukoplakia

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient presents with the following lesion on the lateral aspect of the tongue as shown in the image below. This white membrane was not scrapeable with a gauze piece. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral Hairy Leucoplakia

 

Option A:

 

Oral Hairy Leukoplakia:

 

  • This condition is characterized by a white, corrugated, "hairy" plaque typically found on the lateral borders of the tongue.
  • It is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV.
  • The white membrane is not scrapeable, which helps to distinguish it from candidiasis.
  • The presence of this lesion in an immunocompromised patient that is non-scrapeable strongly indicates Oral Hairy Leukoplakia, which is associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lichen Planus:

 

  • This condition usually presents as white, lace-like patterns (Wickham's striae) as shown in the image below, on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and other oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It can sometimes have erosive, painful areas, but it does not have the "hairy" appearance typical of Oral Hairy Leukoplakia.

 

Option C. Lichen Sclerosus:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that typically affects the anogenital area, not the oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It is characterized by white patches that can lead to scarring, but it does not occur on the tongue.

 

Option D. Candidiasis:

 

  • Also known as oral thrush, candidiasis presents with white patches that typically can be scraped off to reveal a red, bleeding surface underneath. The fact that the lesion in the image is not scrapeable makes candidiasis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in immunocompromised patients.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 25.33

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism seen with deficiency of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace element involved in numerous aspects of cellular metabolism. It plays a vital role in immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. Zinc is also crucial for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, and it is necessary for the proper functioning of taste and smell.

 

Features of Zinc Deficiency:

 

  • Decreased Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in children and adolescents can lead to growth retardation and delayed sexual maturation, particularly hypogonadism in males.
  • Hypogonadism: This condition is characterized by the underdevelopment of primary or secondary sexual characteristics, such as the testes in males, leading to delayed or absent puberty.
  • Impaired Immune Function: Zinc deficiency can result in an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Other Symptoms: Include hair loss, diarrhea, delayed wound healing, and eye and skin lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Deficiency can lead to anemia (microcytic, hypochromic), neutropenia, bone abnormalities, and neurological issues such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Selenium: Deficiency can cause Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy).

 

Option D. Iron: Deficiency is commonly associated with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is associated with decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism, particularly in male children, and is a common nutritional deficiency in developing countries. It is also linked to impaired growth, immune dysfunction, and delayed wound healing.

questions.text: Which structure forms the lateral boundary of the Hasselbach’s triangle? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior epigastric vessels

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle is formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

 

The Hasselbalch triangle is an important anatomical region related to the anterior abdominal wall and is relevant to the understanding of inguinal hernias.

 

The Hasselbalch triangle's boundaries are formed by the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the rectus abdominis muscle medially, and the inguinal ligament forming the base.

 

This triangle is discussed in the context of inguinal hernias, where a direct inguinal hernia occurs when the hernia protrudes through the Hasselbalch triangle, while an indirect inguinal hernia occurs outside of this triangle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vessels: The femoral vessels are not mentioned as forming the lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle.

 

Option C. Inguinal ligament: The inguinal ligament forms the base of the Hasselbalch triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option D. Rectus abdominis: The rectus abdominis muscle forms the medial boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle, an important anatomical region related to inguinal hernias, is formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

questions.text: A bus conductor presents with dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm in the foot. What is the stage of clinical classification according to CEAP (Clinical-etiology-anatomy-pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C2

 

Explanation:

 

The CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders categorizes the severity of venous disease based on clinical signs, etiology, anatomy, and pathophysiology. In this system, the "C" (Clinical) classification is particularly useful for describing the visible and palpable signs of venous disease.

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins. This stage is characterized by dilated, tortuous veins that are generally more than 3 mm in diameter, such as the 4 mm veins described in the patient's case.
  • C3: Edema related to venous disease.

 

Given the description of dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm, the patient's condition corresponds to C2 in the CEAP classification, indicating the presence of varicose veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C0: C0 indicates no visible or palpable signs of venous disease, which does not apply to this patient who has visible varicose veins.

 

Option B. C1: C1 indicates the presence of telangiectasias or reticular veins, which are smaller than 3 mm in diameter. This stage does not describe the 4 mm varicose veins observed in this patient.

 

Option D. C3: C3 is used to classify edema related to chronic venous disorders. This does not match the presentation of dilated, tortuous veins without mentioned edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of dilated, tortuous veins larger than 3 mm, such as the 4 mm veins observed in the patient's foot, corresponds to stage C2 in the CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders, indicating varicose veins.

choices.text: Type I vWD presents with severe bleeding since birth
Type II vWD has reduced activity of von Willebrand factor
Type III vWD has very low levels of von Willebrand factor
Type III vWD presents clinically as a severe disease

questions.text: Which of the following is false about von Willebrand disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I vWD presents with severe bleeding since birth

 

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and is classified into three main types: Type I, Type II, and Type III.

 

  • Type I vWD is the most common form and is characterized by a mild reduction in the quantity of von Willebrand factor (vWF). It typically presents with mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding rather than severe bleeding from birth, making option A false.
  • Type II vWD involves a qualitative defect of vWF, leading to reduced activity rather than quantity, and presents with moderate bleeding tendencies.
  • Type III vWD is the most severe form, with very low levels or complete absence of vWF, leading to severe bleeding symptoms. This type is rare but clinically severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type II vWD has reduced activity of von Willebrand factor: This statement is true as Type II vWD is characterized by a functional defect in the von Willebrand factor, affecting its activity rather than the amount.

 

Option C. Type III vWD has very low levels of von Willebrand factor: This is correct; Type III vWD is associated with very low or absent levels of vWF, causing severe bleeding tendencies.

 

Option D. Type III vWD presents clinically as a severe disease: This is true. Due to extremely low levels of vWF, Type III vWD is associated with severe clinical manifestations, including spontaneous bleeding episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I von Willebrand disease presents with mild to moderate bleeding and is the least severe form, contrasting with Type III, which has very low vWF levels and presents as a severe disease.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with nausea, vomiting, edema and ascites. He had severely deranged liver function tests and a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma was diagnosed. Which of the following is important in the pathogenesis of this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aflatoxin

 

Aflatoxin, produced by the fungus Aspergillus flavus, is a potent hepatotoxin and carcinogen. Chronic exposure to aflatoxin is strongly associated with the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), particularly in regions where food contamination with this toxin is common. Aflatoxin causes mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor gene, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation and cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benzene: Benzene is primarily associated with hematological malignancies such as leukemia, not hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Chronic arsenic exposure is linked to skin cancer, lung cancer, and bladder cancer, but it is not a primary cause of HCC.

 

Option D. Vinyl chloride: Vinyl chloride exposure is associated with angiosarcoma of the liver, a different type of liver cancer, rather than hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deferoxamine

 

Iron overdose, particularly with ferrous sulfate tablets, can lead to severe toxicity. Ingesting more than 60 mg/kg of elemental iron is considered potentially lethal. Acute iron poisoning presents with gastrointestinal symptoms initially and can progress to metabolic acidosis, shock, and multi-organ failure.

 

The presence of acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis is an important indicator of severe iron toxicity and an indication for the administration of an antidote. The appropriate antidote for acute iron intoxication is deferoxamine. Deferoxamine chelates free iron, forming a water-soluble complex that is excreted in the urine, thereby reducing iron's toxic effects on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activated charcoal: Activated charcoal is not effective in cases of iron poisoning. It does not adsorb metals like iron and can be harmful in certain situations like heavy metal poisoning, alcohols, petroleum products, and caustic substances.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Dimercaprol is used for chelation therapy in heavy metal poisoning (e.g., arsenic, mercury, gold) but is not effective for iron poisoning.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is another chelating agent, typically used for conditions such as Wilson's disease (copper overload) and rheumatoid arthritis. It is not effective in treating iron toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute iron intoxication with signs of toxicity such as acidosis, the antidote of choice is deferoxamine. Activated charcoal is not effective in iron poisoning and should not be used.

questions.text: Imaging modality of choice for fistula in Ano is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRI

 

Fistula-in-ano is an abnormal tract that communicates between the inner surface of the anal canal and the outer skin. The main concern with this condition is the recurrence after treatment, making accurate mapping of the fistulous tract essential.

 

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is the gold standard for imaging fistula-in-ano. It provides high-resolution images that can accurately detail the course, depth, and branches of a fistulous tract. MRI can also differentiate between active and inactive tracts, identify secondary extensions, and help in delineating the relationship of the fistula with the sphincter muscles. This makes it invaluable for both diagnosis and preoperative planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PET-CT: PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography) is an imaging modality that is primarily used for detecting and monitoring the progression or regression of cancers.

 

Option C. Sinogram: A sinogram involves injecting contrast into the external opening of a fistula to delineate its course and internal opening on radiographs. While it can provide information about the fistula's course, it may not provide comprehensive information about secondary tracts, the condition of the surrounding tissues, or the relationship with the sphincter muscles.

 

Option D. CT: CT (Computed Tomography) can provide a detailed image of the anatomy and can be used to identify fistula-in-ano. However, it may not be as sensitive or detailed as MRI, especially when it comes to evaluating the small intricacies of the fistula tract or its relationship with the sphincter complex.

 

Fistulae are classified according to Park’s classification.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The imaging modality of choice for evaluating fistula-in-ano is MRI due to its high-resolution imaging capabilities, which provide detailed information about the course, depth, branches of the fistula tract, and its relationship with surrounding structures.

questions.text: Who will give permission for MTP for a woman who is mentally unsound? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legal guardian

 

Explanation:

 

For a woman who is mentally unsound, the permission for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) cannot be given by herself due to her compromised mental state. The legal requirement is that the consent must come from her legal guardian. A legal guardian is an individual who has been legally appointed to care for and make decisions on behalf of the mentally unsound person. This guardian may be a parent or another individual assigned by the court, but the key requirement is that the guardian must have legal authority to make such decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Self: A mentally unsound woman is not legally capable of giving consent for MTP due to her compromised mental state.

 

Option B. Partner: While a partner may be involved in the decision-making process, they do not have the legal authority to give permission for MTP unless they are also the legal guardian.

 

Option C. Parent: Although a parent might be a legal guardian, simply being a parent does not automatically grant the authority. The person must be legally recognized as the guardian.

 

Educational objective:

 

The legal guardian must give permission for MTP for a woman who is mentally unsound, ensuring that the decision is made in the best interest of the patient.

questions.text: A patient with mild to moderate renal failure requires reversal of muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this purpose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

 

Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant used during surgeries to facilitate intubation and muscle relaxation. After the procedure, it is often necessary to reverse the effects of vecuronium to allow the patient to regain muscle function.

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent (SRBA) specifically designed to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, including vecuronium and rocuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecules, effectively reducing their availability to bind to nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, thereby reversing muscle paralysis.

 

Sugammadex is preferred in patients with mild to moderate renal failure because it is highly effective and works faster than traditional agents like neostigmine. While Sugammadex is contraindicated in severe or end-stage renal disease due to reduced clearance, it can be safely used in mild to moderate renal impairment.

 

Note –

 

Reversal agents for muscle relaxants used in anesthesia include neostigmine and Sugammadex.

 

Neostigmine:

 

  • A cholinergic drug that inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to increased acetylcholine.
  • Causes cholinergic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine.
  • Can be used for all muscle relaxants.
  • Can be given in renal disease patients
  • If neostigmine is not an option and the patient has mild to moderate renal failure, Sugammadex is the preferred choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is primarily used to reverse the effects of central nervous system depressants and is not typically used for reversing non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium.

 

Option B. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is used in the management of Alzheimer's disease and other types of dementia, not for reversing muscle relaxants.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used for short-term muscle relaxation, such as during intubation. It is not used for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium and, in fact, would induce more muscle relaxation rather than reverse it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the appropriate agent for reversing the effects of vecuronium in patients with mild to moderate renal failure due to its specific action on non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and its faster onset of action.

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tangier’s disease

 

Tangier's disease is an inherited disorder characterized by significantly reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood. This condition can lead to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and organs. Individuals with Tangier's disease may have enlarged orange tonsils and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease as shown in the picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman's Disease: Wolman's disease is a severe form of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) deficiency, a rare genetic disorder. It is characterized by the complete absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the buildup of fats in various tissues and organs. Symptoms typically appear in infancy and may include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), diarrhea/steatorrhea (fatty stools), and vomiting. This condition can be life-threatening.

 

Option B. Gaucher's Disease: Gaucher's disease is another genetic disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It results in the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucocerebroside in various organs and tissues, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Common symptoms include an enlarged spleen and liver, anemia, low platelet counts, and bone abnormalities. There are different types of Gaucher's disease, and the severity can vary.

 

Option D. Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system. It is caused by the absence or deficiency of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A, which leads to the buildup of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nerve cells. Symptoms typically appear in early childhood and include developmental regression, loss of motor skills, and a cherry-red spot in the eye. Tay-Sachs disease is progressive and ultimately fatal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia

 

ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).

 

  • So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Enlarged lymph nodes
    • Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals. It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase

choices.text: POP for 3 months

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding for two months. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

Explanation:

 

The next line of management in a 50-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) is an endometrial biopsy. This is crucial to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy, especially in a peri-menopausal woman.

 

Indications for Endometrial Sampling:

 

  • Peri-menopausal women with AUB.
  • Hyperestrogenic states like obesity or tamoxifen treatment with thickened endometrium on transvaginal sonography (TVS).
  • Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound findings of endometrial thickness >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women.

 

Methods of Endometrial Sampling:

 

  • Curettage
  • Aspiration biopsy using Pipelle or Vibra aspirator

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LNG-IUCD: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUCD) is a treatment option but should be considered after ruling out malignancy.

 

Option B. POP for 3 months: Progestin-only pills (POP) can be used to manage AUB, but endometrial sampling should be done first to rule out malignancy.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment but is considered after other management options and ruling out malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In peri-menopausal women presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, the first step is to perform endometrial sampling to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy before considering other treatment modalities.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg184

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of cholecystectomy 4 years back for gallstones presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a stone in the common bile duct. What is the most probable type of stone causing this obstruction? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary  

 

The classification of common bile duct (CBD) stones helps determine the probable type and origin of the stones.

 

  • Primary bile duct stones, also known as primary choledocholithiasis, form directly within the bile duct. They are distinct from gallbladder stones.
  • Their formation is typically associated with bile stasis, infection, or parasitic infestation of the bile ducts, particularly the liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis, which is endemic in some parts of Asia.
  •  These stones are often pigmented.
  •  The fact that this patient developed a stone in the common bile duct following a cholecystectomy >2 years back suggests the stone might be a primary stone, forming due to some underlying bile duct pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary: Secondary bile duct stones, or secondary choledocholithiasis, refer to gallstones that formed in the gallbladder and then migrated into the bile duct. This is the most common cause of bile duct stones in patients who still have their gallbladders. Secondary stones are typically cholesterol stones, being yellowish and softer than primary stones.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Tertiary stones are essentially advanced secondary stones. They are stones that have resided in the ductal system for a long time after migrating from the gallbladder, and over time, they might undergo changes due to recurrent bouts of cholangitis or prolonged bile stasis.

 

Option D. Retained: Retained stones refer to stones that were overlooked or missed during an initial procedure, like a cholecystectomy. They should be diagnosed within 2 years of cholecystectomy. They remain in the bile duct and can later cause symptoms. These stones were originally in the gallbladder or bile duct at the time of surgery and were not adequately removed or were missed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary bile duct stones form directly within the bile ducts and are associated with underlying bile duct pathology.
  • They are different from secondary stones, which form in the gallbladder and migrate into the bile duct, and retained stones, which are missed during the initial surgery.

questions.text: What type of sanitation facilities should be provided for the refugees returning from war in a camp? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trench latrine

 

For temporary sanitation facilities in refugee camps, the recommended options are shallow trench latrines, deep trench latrines, pit latrines, and borehole latrines. Among the given choices, the "trench latrine" option is the most appropriate for providing sanitation facilities to refugees returning from war in a camp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pit method - This option is incorrect because the " Pit method " is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps

 

Option B. Dumping method - This option is incorrect because the "dumping method" is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps.

 

Option D. Aqua privy - Aqua privies, which are similar to septic tanks, are useful at the family level but not recommended for temporary refugee camps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When providing temporary sanitation facilities for refugees in camps, trench latrines (either shallow or deep) are the recommended option, as they are suitable for short-term use and can be easily set up in such situations.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-emetic drugs can result in extrapyramidal adverse effects? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metoclopramide

 

Metoclopramide can result in extrapyramidal adverse effects, particularly with prolonged use. It works by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain, which can lead to symptoms similar to those seen in Parkinson's disease, such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Domperidone: While it's a dopamine antagonist like metoclopramide, domperidone does not readily cross the blood-brain barrier and is unlikely to cause extrapyramidal effects.

 

Option B. Ondansetron: This is a 5-HT3 antagonist used to prevent nausea and vomiting, and it does not cause extrapyramidal side effects.

 

Option D. Promethazine: An antihistamine and antiemetic, promethazine may cause sedation and anticholinergic effects, but unlikely to. be associated with extrapyramidal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metoclopramide can result in extrapyramidal adverse effects due to its dopamine receptor antagonist activity in the brain, leading to symptoms similar to Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yolk sac and amniotic sac

 

Explanation:

 

The double bleb sign is due to the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

 

On USG, gestational sac contains the yolk sac and amniotic sac which appear as two small bubbles known as the double bleb sign.

 

It is seen at 7.5 – 8 weeks.

 

Do not confuse with Double decidual sign

 

 

Double decidual sign – true gestational sac surrounded by two layers – decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis with fluid collection in between.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Twin pregnancy: This would involve two separate gestational sacs or distinct embryonic structures in a single sac, not the double bleb sign of a single gestational sac.

 

Option B. Amnion and chorion: These are two layers surrounding the embryo, but the double bleb sign specifically refers to the early visualization of the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

 

Option D. Heterotopic pregnancy: Involves simultaneous intrauterine and extrauterine pregnancies. This would not specifically relate to the double bleb sign, which is a normal ultrasound finding in a single intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The double bleb sign is a normal ultrasound finding in early pregnancy, showing the presence of both the yolk sac and the amniotic sac within the gestational sac, important for confirming a normal early intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has malaise for 2 weeks. His investigations revealed an elevated creatinine of 4.5mg/dl. His blood tests also showed the presence of HBs antigen. A renal biopsy was performed which demonstrated spike and dome on special staining. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranous glomerulopathy

 

The elderly patient is having a renal dysfunction. The presence of a ‘spike and dome’ pattern on special staining (silver staining) is suggestive of immune complex deposition. This is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy. The diagnosis isd also supported by the presence of HBs antigen as the hepatitis B infection is characteristically associated with development of membranous glomerulopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: Typically presents with nephrotic syndrome in children and does not show the spike and dome pattern on biopsy. No change on light microscopy; Electron microscopy shows podocyte effacement

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli, not associated with the spike and dome pattern.

 

Option D. Renal amyloidosis: Demonstrates amyloid deposits that can be identified with Congo red staining and apple-green birefringence under polarized light, not a spike and dome pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous glomerulopathy, associated with hepatitis B infection, presents with nephrotic syndrome and demonstrates a characteristic spike and dome pattern on renal biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposits.

 

Histology: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

questions.text: The rate-limiting enzyme of HMP shunt is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

 

The rate-limiting enzyme of the Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). G6PD catalyzes the first step in this pathway, converting glucose-6-phosphate into 6-phosphoglucono-δ-lactone while reducing NADP+ to NADPH.

 

This step is crucial for the production of NADPH, which is necessary for reductive biosynthesis and for maintaining the reduced state of glutathione, thereby protecting cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis but not in the HMP shunt. It catalyzes the final step of these pathways, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose in the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase I (PFK1): PFK1 is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis, not the HMP shunt. It catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.

 

Option D. Glycogen phosphorylase: This enzyme is the rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis, where it breaks down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate. It is not involved in the HMP shunt.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rate Limiting Enzymes

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine induces this through its effect on renal handling of water by affecting antidiuretic hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rashes: Rashes are more common with carbamazepine due to its propensity to cause allergic skin reactions.

 

Option C. Blood dyscrasias: Blood dyscrasias, including agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, are more associated with carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hepatitis: Hepatitis and other liver dysfunctions are more often linked to carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

questions.text: An HIV patient came to the clinic with a history of diarrhea. Stool microscopy showed the oocysts that were 4-8 µm in size. The image is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptosporidium

 

The given clinical scenario and the stool microscopy show oocysts of Cryptosporidium.

 

Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite. The two cryptosporidium species responsible for traveller’s diarrhoea are C. hominis and C. parvum.

 

 

Sporulated oocysts, containing 4 sporozoites, are excreted by the infected host through feces image (and possibly other routes such as respiratory secretions).

 

Transmission of Cryptosporidium spp. occurs mainly through ingestion of fecally contaminated water (e.g., drinking or recreational water) or food (e.g., raw milk) or following direct contact with infected animals or people.

 

Following ingestion (and possibly inhalation) by a suitable host image, excystation occurs. The sporozoites are released and parasitize the epithelial cells of the gastrointestinal tract (and possibly the respiratory tract).

 

In these cells, usually within the brush border, the parasites undergo asexual multiplication (schizogony or merogony) and then sexual multiplication (gametogony) producing microgamonts (male) image and macrogamonts (female).

 

Upon fertilization of the macrogamonts by the microgametes that rupture from the macrogamont, oocysts develop and sporulate in the infected host.

 

Zygotes give rise to two different types of oocysts (thick-walled and thin-walled. Thick-walled oocysts are excreted from the host into the environment, whereas thin-walled oocysts are involved in the internal autoinfective cycle and are not recovered from stools.

 

Oocysts are infectious upon excretion, thus enabling direct and immediate fecal-oral transmission.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Isospora (now Cystoisospora): Isospora belli oocysts are larger, measuring about 20-30 µm by 10-19 µm. They typically contain two sporocysts, each with four sporozoites. Isosporiasis is less common than cryptosporidiosis and presents with gastrointestinal symptoms in immunocompromised individuals. Isospora oocysts are acid-fast but larger than Cryptosporidium.

 

Option B. Cyclospora cayetanensis oocysts are also coccidian parasites but are slightly larger, measuring about 8-10 µm in diameter. Cyclospora infections can cause prolonged diarrhea but are distinguished by their size and autofluorescence under ultraviolet light, which is different from Cryptosporidium.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microsporidia are obligate intracellular parasites that also cause diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients. However, their spores are much smaller (1-2 µm) and they do not exhibit the same morphological characteristics as Cryptosporidium oocysts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium oocysts are small (4-8 µm) coccidian parasites responsible for causing diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. They are identified in stool samples by their size and acid-fast staining properties.

questions.text: The chronic alcoholic patient had a history of strenuous exercise but forgot to take his meal, later had alcohol in a party, and presented with hypoglycemia. Which of the following processes is inhibited by alcohol? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gluconeogenesis

 

Alcohol metabolism involves the conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde and then to acetic acid. Both steps generate NADH through the actions of alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase, respectively. The excessive production of NADH in the liver causes a shift in the metabolic equilibrium.

 

Increased levels of NADH favor the conversion of pyruvate to lactate (lactic acidosis) and oxaloacetate to malate. Since pyruvate and oxaloacetate are key substrates for gluconeogenesis (the process of generating glucose from non-carbohydrate sources), their depletion inhibits gluconeogenesis. This metabolic inhibition leads to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted, as in the case of the patient who had undergone strenuous exercise and had not eaten.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogenolysis: This process, which involves the breakdown of glycogen to glucose, is not directly inhibited by alcohol. However, once glycogen stores are depleted, the body relies on gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels, which is impaired by alcohol.

 

Option B. HMP shunt: The Hexose Monophosphate shunt (also known as the Pentose Phosphate Pathway) is involved in generating NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate but is not directly affected by alcohol metabolism.

 

Option D. Ketone bodies synthesis: While chronic alcohol consumption can lead to ketoacidosis, the synthesis of ketone bodies is not inhibited by alcohol. Instead, alcohol can lead to a buildup of acetyl-CoA, which can actually promote ketogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol metabolism produces excess NADH, which inhibits gluconeogenesis by depleting pyruvate and oxaloacetate, leading to hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Patient has problems in doing heel to shin test and repeatedly misses, and he has tremors in his hands. What is the likely site of lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cerebellum

 

Explanation

 

The heel-to-shin test is a classic test for cerebellar function, and difficulty or inaccuracy in performing this test indicates cerebellar dysfunction.

 

Additionally, the presence of tremors, particularly intention tremors, is characteristic of cerebellar lesions.

 

Cerebellar dysfunction can also present with other signs such as dysdiadochokinesia (difficulty with rapid alternating movements), dysmetria (inability to judge distance or scale), nystagmus, and ataxia (uncoordinated movement).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caudate: Lesions in the caudate nucleus are associated with chorea, characterized by involuntary, irregular, and unpredictable movements.

 

Option C. Globus pallidus: Lesions here typically result in dystonia and rigidity, not tremors or difficulty with the heel-to-shin test.

 

Option D. Pyramidal tract: Lesions in the pyramidal tract lead to spasticity, increased muscle tone, and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, not the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebellar lesions are indicated by difficulties with coordination tests such as the heel-to-shin test, presence of intention tremors, and other signs of ataxia. Recognizing these features helps in localizing the lesion to the cerebellum.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of AMTSL? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) was described by the WHO in 2007 and involves mainly three basic steps:

 

  1. Administering a uterotonic: Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV).
  2. Controlled cord traction: This is done only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
  3. Uterine massage: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who have received uterotonics; instead, postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.

 

Key Points:

 

  • AMTSL prevents atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care. This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed.

 

WHO Guidelines:

 

  • In 2012:
    • Emphasized the main three steps.
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice.
    • Controlled cord traction only with a skilled birth attendant.
    • Delayed cord clamping recommended.
  • In 2018:
    • Additional uterotonics that can be used include:
      • Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV)
      • Misoprostol (400 or 600 mcg PO – to be used where a skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
      • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV except in hypertensive women)
      • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
    • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonics after delivery of placenta: This is a key component of AMTSL to prevent atonic PPH.

 

Option B. Controlled cord traction: This is part of the AMTSL process to help deliver the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine massage: This is included in AMTSL, specifically for assessing uterine tone post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct components of AMTSL include administering a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage. Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL; instead, delayed cord clamping is recommended.

questions.text: In an automobile manufacturing company, the HR department notes an increase in absenteeism among the factory workers over the past six months. The company collaborates with a public health expert to investigate the reasons. The expert decides to use the metric of sickness absenteeism as a tool. What is the primary aspect this metric would evaluate? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Health of the worker

 

Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is used as an indicator of the occupational health of the employees. High sickness absenteeism indicates poor occupational health of the workers.

 

Sickness absenteeism is a ‘useful index in industry to assess the state of health of workers’, and their physical, mental and social well-being. Rate of absenteeism reported in India is 8 – 10 days per worker per year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Health of the family: Sickness absenteeism does not directly assess the health of the worker's family.

 

Option C. Industrial environment: While the industrial environment can affect absenteeism, the metric specifically evaluates worker health.

 

Option D. Community health: Sickness absenteeism focuses on the health of the workers, not the broader community.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickness absenteeism primarily evaluates the health of the worker and is a key indicator of occupational health.

 

Methods of reducing sickness absenteeism:

 

  • Good factory management and practices
  • Adequate pre-placement examination
  • Good human relations
  • Application of ergonomics

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth. (BNS 229)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (up to 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 7 years. (BNS 238)

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. After the incubation period of 5 - 15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills. By around 4 - 5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

 

The infection can be transmitted by

 

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva

 

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal.

 

Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

 

Educational Objective

 

Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles. Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient visits you with inflammatory alopecia. This type of hair loss is commonly associated with which variant of tinea capitis infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Favus and Kerion

 

Favus and kerion are the inflammatory variants of tinea capitis.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy. It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms:  Zoophilic dermatophytes i.e., T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum àGriseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Endothrix and Favus and Option D: Kerion and Endothrix Endothrix infections involve the growth of fungi within the hair shaft without external spore formation and typically present with less inflammation compared to Kerion and Favus.

 

Option B: Ectothrix and Endothrix Ectothrix infections, where the fungus grows on the outside of the hair shaft and breaks the hair off at the scalp surface, are typically associated with non-inflammatory forms of alopecia such as the 'grey patch' type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammatory alopecia is commonly associated with the favus and kerion variants of tinea capitis, which can cause scarring and permanent hair loss due to the significant inflammatory response.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Page no 32.39-40, 89.35

questions.text: What is the next best step in the management of a 16-year-old male with a painless large round firm right testicular swelling, with a dragging sensation and AFP around 5000? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High inguinal orchidectomy

 

Testicular mass with elevated AFP is suggestive of testicular tumor, where the next best step in management for this patient is High inguinal orchidectomy

 

This is the correct choice for the initial management of a suspected malignant testicular tumor. The inguinal approach ensures that the scrotal skin and potential lymphatic drainage are not violated. This procedure allows for both definitive diagnosis (through histopathological examination) and therapeutic management by removing the tumor. An elevated AFP further supports the possibility of a germ cell tumor, such as a yolk sac tumor or non-seminomatous germ cell tumor, both of which warrant surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): While FNAC is a diagnostic procedure, it's not typically used in the primary evaluation of testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding along the needle track and is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Scrotal trucut biopsy: This is not recommended for suspected testicular tumors. Biopsying a testicular tumor through a scrotal approach can risk tumor spillage or seeding within the scrotum and can alter the lymphatic drainage pattern, thus complicating future treatment..

 

Option D. Repeat Tumor markers: While monitoring tumor markers like AFP is useful in the management and follow-up of testicular cancer, simply repeating the test without addressing the testicular mass would not be appropriate. The clinical findings and elevated AFP already provide strong evidence of malignancy, and action should be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A painless testicular swelling in a young male with elevated AFP is highly suggestive of a testicular malignancy. The standard of care in such cases is to proceed with a high inguinal orchidectomy for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with 400 ml urine output in 24 hours. On histology he had crescents with pauci immune glomerulonephritis. What is the main etiology? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ANCA

 

The presence of crescents in a pauci-immune glomerulonephritis pattern is characteristic of ANCA-associated vasculitis. This type of vasculitis does not typically involve immune deposits (hence "pauci-immune") and is commonly associated with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). These antibodies are directed against constituents of neutrophil granules and monocyte lysosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti GBM antibody: This antibody targets the glomerular basement membrane, leading to Goodpasture's syndrome, which is typically not pauci-immune.

 

Option C. Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibody: This is primarily associated with primary membranous nephropathy, which shows a different histological pattern.

 

Option D. Anti-nuclear antibody: While antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, which can involve the kidneys, lupus nephritis usually shows immune complex deposition, unlike pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ANCA-associated vasculitis is linked to pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, where crescents are formed in glomeruli without significant immune deposits, differentiating it from conditions such as Goodpasture's syndrome or lupus nephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used to assess the blood stain? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barberio’s test

 

Barberio test is a microchemical test for Semen

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Additional Information

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR SEMEN

 

1) Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

questions.text: A child presented with leukocoria and an intraocular mass. On microscopic examination, Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes with scanty cytoplasm were seen. The mass was also positive for synaptophysin. The diagnosis can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

The correct answer is Retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina typically seen in children, presenting with symptoms such as leukocoria (white reflex in the eye) and an intraocular mass. On microscopic examination, Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which are characteristic circular arrangements of tumor cells around a central lumen, are seen. These rosettes are a hallmark of well-differentiated retinoblastoma. The presence of synaptophysin, a protein found in neuroendocrine tumors, further supports the diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medulloblastoma: Although medulloblastoma, a neuroendocrine tumor of the cerebellum, can also show synaptophysin positivity and similar rosettes, it does not present with leukocoria or an intraocular mass. This tumor typically occurs in the brain, not the eye.

 

Option B. Retinal detachment: Retinal detachment is a condition where the retina separates from its underlying layer but does not involve tumor formation or the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Leukocoria might be seen in severe cases, but synaptophysin positivity is not associated with this condition.

 

Option D. Pinealoblastoma: Pinealoblastoma is a tumor of the pineal gland and may present with neuroendocrine characteristics similar to medulloblastoma, including synaptophysin positivity. However, it does not present with intraocular features like leukocoria or rosettes specific to retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key point to remember is that retinoblastoma presents with leukocoria, an intraocular mass, and characteristic Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on microscopic examination. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children and should be promptly recognized.

questions.text: A child presents with curved lowered spine, shortened arms and legs, poor muscle tone and delayed milestones. His upper arms are affected more than the lower legs. Which of the following   is the inheritance of the disease? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AD

 

Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder that is characterized by dwarfism, with specific features including a curved lower spine (lordosis or kyphosis), shortened arms and legs (rhizomelic shortening), poor muscle tone, and delayed milestones. The upper arms (humerus) are more affected than the lower legs (femur). The condition is caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene and follows an autosomal dominant (AD) inheritance pattern. This means only one copy of the mutated gene, inherited from one parent, is sufficient to cause the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AR (Autosomal Recessive): This pattern requires both parents to pass on a copy of the mutated gene for the disorder to manifest. Achondroplasia does not follow this pattern.

 

Option B. XLD (X-linked Dominant): This inheritance pattern affects both males and females, but is not relevant to achondroplasia.

 

Option C. XLR (X-linked Recessive): This pattern primarily affects males and requires the mother to be a carrier. Achondroplasia does not follow this pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia has autosomal dominant inheritance, requiring only one copy of the mutated FGFR3 gene to cause the disorder.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

D. Mitochondrial - 1. LHON (Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy):

LHON is caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA affecting the optic nerve and leading to vision loss.

 

A. AD (Autosomal Dominant) - 2. Myotonic Dystrophy:

Myotonic Dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by muscle wasting and myotonia, caused by an expanded repeat sequence in the DMPK gene.

 

B. AR (Autosomal recessive) 3. Cystic Fibrosis:

Cystic Fibrosis is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.

 

C. XR (X-Linked Recessive) 4. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy:

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the DMD gene, leading to progressive muscle degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different genetic disorders are inherited through various modes of inheritance: autosomal dominant (e.g., Myotonic Dystrophy), autosomal recessive (e.g., Cystic Fibrosis), X-linked recessive (e.g., Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy), and mitochondrial (e.g., LHON).

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the following EEG finding? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM sleep

 

EEG recording is showing "Sawtooth waves" which are characteristic of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is also associated with rapid eye movements, muscle atonia (paralysis), and dreaming.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Transition between wakefulness and sleep, contains theta waves.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, characterized by delta waves.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep follows NREM sleep. EEG in REM sleep shows sawtooth waves and increased activity similar to awake state (beta activity) along with return of alpha activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 534.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with watery diarrhea and vomiting. Electron microscopy showed the following image. Identify the organism: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotavirus

 

The clinical presentation of watery diarrhea and vomiting in a 2-year-old child, combined with the electron microscopy image showing wheel-like structures, strongly indicates Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is easily identified by its characteristic wheel-like appearance under electron microscopy. The virus is known for causing gastroenteritis in infants and young children, leading to dehydration if not managed properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenovirus: While adenoviruses can cause gastroenteritis, they do not have the characteristic wheel-like appearance seen in electron microscopy. Adenovirus typically presents with a different capsid morphology that lacks the wheel-like structure of Rotavirus.

 

Option C. Norwalk virus: Also known as Norovirus, this virus is a common cause of gastroenteritis but has a distinct cup-like morphology on electron microscopy, not the wheel-like appearance seen with Rotavirus.

 

Option D. Astrovirus: Astrovirus can cause diarrhea in young children, but it has a star-like appearance under electron microscopy, differing from the wheel-like appearance of Rotavirus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is characterized by its distinctive wheel-like appearance on electron microscopy.
